chargeHist.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)
Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th or 6th) and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Troy A. Livingston was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  To be paid monthly through probation.  To be paid in full during term of probation.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

timeConds.notes:
May serve in Trempealeau or Chippewa County.  Huber allowed for verified employment, treatment or therapy.  Last 21 days may be served at the Fahrman Center.
Concurrent with: To be served concurrently with Chippewa County Case No. 15CF131.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

supervisions.notes: AMENDED on 5/3/18 pursuant to Court order.  Days of credit granted.

superMiscConds.notes: Outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If reconfined or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Obtain and maintain employment, commensurate with his treatment needs.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Maintain absolute sobriety.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Maintain absolute sobriety.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  

Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle until properly licensed.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with extended supervision conditions.

records.descr: Amended Judgment of Conviction After Revocation

records.addlTxt: Transcript of Sentencing hearing on revocation held on 4/17/2018

District Attorney Daniel S. Diehn appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Satorius.  Parties have the revocation packet.  No changes or errors noted by either party.  State recommended:  18 months of initial confinement and 24 months extended supervision.  Defense recommended: 18 months of initial confinement and 24 months extended supervision.  Defendant exercised his right to allocution.  

Court ordered:  18 months of initial confinement and 24 months of extended supervision.  Extended supervision conditions:  CC $1769.00 due.  Take from prison wages.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with extended supervision conditions.  Maintain absolute sobriety.  Subject to random testing by his agent.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  AODA and recommended treatment.  Obtain employment, commensurate with his treatment needs.  Credit to be determined between the parties.  If they agree, JOC can be amended by the clerk.  
Defendant is eligible for the substance abuse program.  Defendant is not eligible for the challenge incarceration program.
Sentencing hearing on revocation on April 17, 2018 at 04:00 pm.
Sent to Judge Becker 4/3.  JMM
from DOC

records.descr: Order for intox driver assessment and safety plan

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #1

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Sebion.  Defendant plead no contest to count 1.  Counts 2 and 3 dismissed.  Court advised the defendant of the possible penalties of the charge he is pleading to.  He understood.  Priors confirmed by the court.  Felony warnings given.   Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defendant understood.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea. Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of Count 1. OWI 5th.   Count 3 dismissed.  Count 2 DRI.  Probation 3 years.  Joint recommendation for the guidelines.  $600.00 fine, plus costs.  6 months jail. May serve in Trempeleau or Chippew County Jail w/huber.   Concurrent with Chippewa Co case no. 15cf131.   3 yrs. DL rev & IID.  Alc assmt & dsp.  

Court ordered: sentence withheld, 3 years probation.   $600.00 fine, plus costs.  Pay monthly through probation.  To be paid in full during probation.  6 months jail.  May serve in Trempeleau or Chippewa County Jail w/huber or verified employment, treatment or therapy.    Last 21 days may be served at the Farman Center.  Concurrent with Chippewa Co case no. 15CF131.   3 year driver's license revocation and IID.  Alcohol assessment and driver's safetly plan.  Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Random alc testing.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions. AODA and recommendations.   Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.    Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.
